title: letter-editor-pick-border-telegraph
story: THANK you for visiting the Borderwebsite.Your interest in our articles reminds us that, even in these challenging times, there remains a faith in the importance of local news.Our small editorial team- working from home - is always delighted to hear your tales of success, keen to give you a  to inspire others.Those sparks of light are perhaps as vital to readers now as they have ever been in our letimes.All the while, though, we shall continue to perform that other greatof journalism - monitoring the exercise of power.Because even during this shutdown, when the usual rules do not always apply, big decisions will still be taken and our lives will still be affected.In short, the Borderand its staff want to serve you - our readers - as effectively as possible through the virus-era and beyond.However, our ability to do that depends on your support. Thank you again for visiting our website, a service we are proud to maintain, but I would also invite you to purchase a print edition whenever you can.You might even wish to start picking up an extra copy for your neighbour, especiallythey are elderly or vulnerable.Many newsagents are offering home delivery services - perhaps that is another option worth exploring.And do not forget that we also produce an e-edition of the newspaper, a page-by-page replica of the physical copy, which you can download for  pence through this link.With your backing and encouragement, the Borderwill weather this storm - allowing us to print your smile on the other side.Thank you again and best wishes,Andrew McQuarrieContent Editor

title: hawick-librarian-turns-declaration-arbroath-scots
story: A SCHOOL librarian has produced what is believed to be the first accessible Scots translation of the Declaration of Arbroath.Thomas Clark, of Hawick, worked alongside friend Ashley Douglas to complete the piece, which is now displayed on the website of the National Library of Scotland.Mr Clark, , told us: ldquoWhat was really gratying was seeing so many people realising theyrsquod been missing a Scots translation.The th anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroathrsquos creation was on April . The documentrsquos most famous excerpt is a statement of Scottish independence.Mr Clark, who works at Hawick High School, has previously completed Scots translations of a number of popular books.The focus of his latest effort, however, was rather dferent in style to previous inspirations, which include Diary of a Wimpy Kid.It took Mr Clark and Ms Douglas around three months to convert the Declaration into our native language.Asked where his interest in Scots came from, Mr Clark said it was his move to the Borders  years ago which kick-started his love affair.ldquoI spoke Scots in Hamilton and so did my friends but I was under the impression it was just bad English ndash it was knocked out of you, said Mr Clark.ldquoBut then I came to the Borders and found that a lot of people not only spoke Scots, but spoke it without a social stigma.Reflecting on the Declaration, Mr Clark believes Scots have a strange relationship with the document.ldquoItrsquos funny that we have this text thatrsquos basically the birth certicate of the whole country, but therersquos not a lot of knowledge about it, said Mr Clark, going on to outline his views on its signicance.ldquoAt root, itrsquos a revolutionary document. Itrsquos a country asserting its right to be a country and its right to choose its own ruler.ldquoWe should be a lot more proud about Scotland being one of the first countries to assert itself in this way.Mr Clark says he supports Scottish independence, but he is keen for the Declaration to appeal to nationalists and unionists alike.He said: ldquoI think itrsquos really important the Declaration of Arbroath is not part of a political wrangle. People of every stripe in Scotland should see this as being part of the heritage.

We are processing applications and payments as soon as possible, but I would reiterate once again that it is essential that the application form is completed fully and all relevant additional information provided to make the process as quick as possible for all concerned.Last week, she said the council had been ldquoinundated with applications.She added then that the aim was to process submissions within  days.Chairman of South of Scotland Enterprise Russel Griggs said last week: ldquoIt is great that payments are starting to be made to eligible businesses.Funding takes the form of pound, and pound, grants. title: toys-tablets-trampolines-additional-support-kids
story: CHILDREN with additional needs are embracing new toys, trampolines and tablet devices after a support group secured pound, in National Lottery funding.Borders Additional Needs Group , which assists more than  families, is aiming to boost its reach during the coronavirus pandemic.It has purchased sensory toys, special equipment, tablets for youngsters unable to see friends or family due to social-distancing, trampolines, outdoor equipment, and compression blankets.The charity is also hoping to purchase tablets for parents with limited access to such resources.BANGs chief executive officer Pauline Grigor told us: "During these challenging times of social restrictions, ASNchildren can find this particularly dficult due to their sensory needs. This funding will offer some support for them and their families."We have dedicated telephone support lines receiving calls from families in distress and anxiety."We are working with partner organisations, Meeting of Minds, and EPIC, to collaborate and coordinate a Scottish Borders-wide response."Since lockdown began, the volunteer-led group has been working the phones and social media ndash and providing delivery and outreach services.During the Easter Bank Holiday weekend, they even dropped off a selection of Easter eggs to Borders families."I took eggs to those I could reach," Pauline said. "The kids were delighted ndash one said he wanted to give me a hug and was sad about not being able to."BANG is currently made up of eight volunteers ndash down from its usual team of  ndash who work  hours a day. Many regular volunteers have taken time away from the charity due to the ongoing COVID- crisis, with some acting as parent carers or shielding.Pauline added: "BANG is a community of unsung heroes."NHS workers, cleaners, and truck drivers are all amazing, but we have volunteers working tirelessly behind the scenes because they care about the community."The latest funding has allowed the charity to approve support applications from  families over the last  days, delivering  sensory toys to children in need.Howevr, a further blow to the charity has been its inability to celebrate success at last months National Youth Awards, where it won the Equality and Diversity award for its BANG Summer Camp.At the awards, service user Olivia Robertson, , joined Pauline at the ceremony in Glasgow, even running on stage to collect the gong. Pauline told us that although Olivia had started the night feeling anxious due to a sensory reaction to the environment, by the end of the night she was talking away with journalists. She even called her mum after stepping off stage, saying: "Mum, Im living my best le".Pauline added: "Money cant buy that night. Seeing her boosted confidence and self-esteem exceeded the award."In the midst of the lockdown, however, BANG has received some good news after being told their funding for the BANG Summer Camp  had been approved."We will be running it," said Pauline. "What the service looks like, were unsure. But theres more of a need for it now for respite than last year."For more information, and to apply for support from BANG, visit: www.bordersadditionalneeds.org

title: teacher-makes-ppe-borders-home-schools-3d-printer
story: A TEACHER is making safety gear for key workers from the kitchen of his Peebles home.Alan Gray, who works at Gracemount High School in Edinburgh, has been producing personal protective equipmentusing a D printer.With a we employed by the NHS as a nurse, Mr Gray told this newspaper he has "a bit of an idea" about frontline workers need.He said: "They are doing a great job and deserve whatever PPE or assistance can be provided.Mr Gray ndash a craft, design and technologyteacher ndash said he decided to take home the schools printer before lockdown so he could print pupils projects.But now the machine is pumping out around  safety visors per day, according to Mr Gray, who was inspired by other teachers tales.He said: ldquoI had been hearing from both Scottish and UK social media teaching communities that teaching staff and technicians were coordinating an effort to manufacture PPE for key workers with the resources they had to hand."Teaming up with other Borders-based staff, Mr Gray began printing with the aim of supplying mainly Peeblesshire-based care workers and the Borders General Hospitalin Melrose.ldquoI used Facebook to try to raise funds to cover the cost of ordering consumables for the task, said Mr Gray. ldquoBut the community response has been overwhelming. Generous financial donations to the cause have totalled over pound. Other donations have included a local supply of printer filament, laminated pouches and hole punch, which has been invaluable."Struggling to keep up with demand, Mr Gray was joined by graphic designer Barry Turner, as well as Norman MacLeod, who designs and manufactures drones.Mr Gray said: ldquoLocal demand for face visors has been huge and I can only print in the region of - visors a day."Two other local people, Barry and Norman, hearing about the problem of supplying PPE to the front line, as well as having access to the necessary equipment, have kindly joined in D printing to try to increase the numbers available.Although the project was spearheaded by one man, it has continued to grow with the support and generosity of the community, the help of volunteers, and, of course, Gracemount Highrsquos printer.Mr Gray said: ldquoI actually brought it home to figure out how to use it and itrsquos easier to print pupilsrsquo projects at weekends. I didnrsquot know there would be a PPE shortage. It was just luck really.

title: peebles-dancers-enjoy-online-classes-lockdown
story: DANCING queens and kings across Peeblesshire have kept their toes tapping during the lockdown thanks to online classes from the Fiona Henderson School of Dance .After holding their last face-to-face class on March , FHSD has been forced to go digital with classes for pupils.In the first week of virtual classes, beginning March , FHSD ran a total of  sessions, including those for their Little Stars, Irish dancing beginners, and their graded ballet and tap pupils.School principal Fiona Henderson told us: "We did some initial planning in anticipation of having to move some classes online but that weekend was a whirlwind of activity getting all the technology in place, new timetable finalised as well as ensuring all the teachers were trained and established in their new home-studios."Fiona has praised the schools ability to transition with ease during what was predicted to be a dficult time for the dance school.All classes are up and running online, with teachers leading pupils over the video conferencing app Zoom. The only class which has not been carried across to the app is Acrowhich was axed due to health and safety concerns."Itrsquos important that pupils retain their fitness and general wellbeing during this lockdown period," said Fiona.ldquoOur classes are lsquobusiness as usualrsquo as far as it is possible using the online classrooms."Our pupils are continuing to learn ndash each class will be focusing on dferent things in dferent subjects and grades, but in general they will be continuing to learn technique, exam syllabus content and routines for their forthcoming shows and performances."Fiona added: ldquoThe lockdown is affecting people in dferent ways. I know all our teachers are really missing our pupils, so itrsquos great being able to see them and be with them lsquovirtuallyrsquo in the meantime.Every -minute class has to begin on the hour to make the most of the teaching. And theory-based work has also been introduced to enhance each session.All pupils have to be in the class, in their unorm, five minutes before the start, and are still given homework and at-home practices to work on before their next class.Like many other businesses during the COVID- crisis, FHSD is facing financial problems. But dancers families have been nothing but supportive.Fiona said: "The support from our pupils families has been fantastic and wersquove received lots of lovely messages over the last couple of weeks saying how great it is that our pupils can continue their dancing during the current restrictions and how much it means that they can continue to lsquobe withrsquo their teachers and dance friends.And as the classes have continued, maintaining a sense of normalcy for many of the pupils, one dancer said, "I want to thank you and your team for the fantastic effort all of you have put in to arrange online classes for the students during this dficult time," and another added, "I just wanted to say a huge thank you to you and your teachers for doing what you are doing!! I really enjoy the classes and appreciate all your hard work.",params: .push"Planning too far ahead in the current environment is impossible," added Fiona."The teachers and I are simply focused on our pupils and providing them with the best dance tuition we can."Wersquore all looking forward to getting back to face to face classes ndash and therersquos sure to be a party atmosphere for our first day back in our dance studios."In the meantime, though, wersquore all just aiming to keeping dancing!"For more information, visit: www.fionahendersondance

title: feature-animal-adoptions-borders-put-hold
story: PETS in need of new homes in the Borders are having to wait for their fairytale endings.The coronavirus outbreak has temporarily put an end to animal adoption across the country.The Borderspoke to four animal rescue centres in the region to learn how they, their volunteers and the animals are coping during the lockdown.Borders Pet Rescue, the providers of our pet of the week feature, looks after a iety of animals, ranging from cats and dogs to exotic reptiles and birds ndash all in need of homes.Lee-Ann Lackie, rescue centre manager, told us: "We are fortunate to have very supportive foster homes that we are using. We have three dogs and three cats in foster that were in place before the lockdown. We are trying to support them as much as possible."Unfortunately, the lockdown means that we cannot re-home any animals at this time. We had people lined up to come and meet two of the dogs on the week that the country went into lockdown and had to cancel their appointments due to this."Also, Pal, who has been waiting for over a year for a new home, was due to go away to his new home that week which has had to be put on hold. And we have no idea when he can finally go to his new home."And the centre isnt just coping with the stress of caring for the animals during a crisis, theyre also facing potential financial strain as the weeks progress."Our centre relies heavily on income generated from our four shops," added Lee-Ann. "Seventy per cent of our annual income is generated via the shops so loss of income is a real concern."We have had to cancel fundraising events during the key fundraising period of spring summer. This includes our Annual Dog Show in May which is one our biggest fundraising events."We are hopeful that not all staff go down with virus at same time."We are managing the situation to the best of our ability and [despite] that our weekly income has reduced very signicantly, and we need people to donate to help keep our centre operational whilst our shops are closed."All our animals are still being looked after and cared for by our excellent and committed staff."Sonia Graham from Borders Greyhound Rescue added: "Were trying to make the best of the situation."We have  dogs at the moment because we cant get dogs in or out. Its dficult."Weve had some under fostering, but unless they are greyhound people they wont be going to foster."Its frustrating because for people who want dogs, youd think this was the perfect time to have one as theres time for one-on-one training."And a lack of volunteers is a key factor in the dficulties facing the Greyhound Rescue now, with the charity normally taking in up to  regular helpers to care for  dogs."Without volunteers, its been a real struggle," said Sonia. "Were family-run and we have a farm too, so were just trying to fill the gaps left by volunteers."Another problem which has reared its head for Sonia and her family is the knock-on effect of this lockdown.Sonia explained: "People who may have lost jobs or their business, they wont be thinking of taking on an animal."People cant afford to pay vet bills. I can see this being a dficult year."If anything, we may see animals being handed in. People will misjudge and panic about the situation. And it wont just be dogs being brought to rescues but being dumped."It will be interesting to see how this all works out."And to help ease the strain on the rescue, Sonia has created an Amazon wishlist for donations to help keep the dogs fed.The wishlist gives donors the option to either donate physical items, such as a bag of food, or they can gt a cash amount straight into the Greyhound Rescues account to spent on vital products.On the other hand, the Arthurshiel Rescue Centre, in St Boswells, hasnt seen an increase in their four-legged residents, with the charity manager Shona Middlemass saying: "Were managing fine".She added: "Weve not had an influx of animals, any strays that get raised with us we share over Facebook."Fingers crossed everything keeps going smoothly, weve not had any problems."We dont have any cash coming in. Cat and dog boarding is our main source of income."Wed normally have five or six dogs, And Easter last year we were full with ten cats boarding."We rely on people going on holiday, and weve now had cancellation right up to July."However, the rescue has received some good news recently.Border Terrier Teddy, who went to a foster home last month, has been dubbed a failed foster, as he is likely to be kept by his foster family, finding his forever home.And its not just your average pets who are being impacted by the pandemic.The Scottish Borders Donkey Sanctuary, which was due to reopen for the Spring season in mid-March, still has donkeys available for adoption and sponsorship, and is operating as business as usual.John from the Sanctuary said: "We hope to continue routine hoof trimming, tetanus booster injections , worming and de-lousingas and when they are due on a welfare basis."All the rescues are doing their best to meet social-distancing guidelines while also ensuring the well-being of their animals.Borders Pet Rescues Lee-Ann added: "Please do not come to the centre and only contact centre by phone or email and the staff will help you as much as they can."If members of the public have any donations for the centre or charity shops, then we ask that you please keep them until it is safe to deliver them."People can donate via our Facebook and web page."For more information on these four rescues, you can find them at: Borders Pet Rescue, www.borderspetrescue.org Scottish Borders Greyhound Rescue, www.greyhoundtrust.org.uk Arthurshiel Rescue Centre, facebook Arthurshiel-Rescue-Centre- and The Scottish Borders Donkey Sanctuary, donkeyheaven.org

title: ex-radio-borders-dj-went-rome-become-priest
story: A Galashiels priest-in-training has spoken to the Borderabout his time in the Vatican and what it was like being filmed by the BBC for a new documentary, which is being aired this weekend.Former Radio Borders DJ Bobby Taylor was in his fth year at The Scots College in Rome when filming for the BBCs Priest School began in September . He is now coming to the end of his sixth year.The -year-old, whose mother is Catholic, had always had the inclination to become a priest, even applying to train before, but for reasons-unknown never followed up on these applications.It wasnt untilgoing to confession in Melbourne in , not long after the passing of his father two years earlier, that he started seeing a path to priesthood laid out clearly in front of him ndash particularly thanks to guidance from his own parish-priest in Galashiels.When we spoke to Bobby, who is back in Galashiels, he told us: "Since filming ended, the most visible thing thats changed is that when were in Rome now were wearing collars. Candidacy is the final step before being admitted as a member of the clergy. So I suppose our wardrobe is the most visible change."When you get into sixth year especially, you start realising youre closer to the end of your time in Rome than you ever have been."Although seven years, when youre in your first year, feels like a very, very long time, when you realise youre a year or maybe  months away from finishing up, you realise just how quickly its all gone ndash how little time youve got left in a beautul city like Rome."Youre looking even more forward than you ever were to getting back and doing what it is that you went to Rome in the first place to do, which is to become a priest."The programme follows a group of young Scots over a year of their seven-year degree, showing the inner workings of the seminary, its history, and how the young seminarians navigate their journey to priesthood.The colleges training isnt for every student, however. The school has an approximate  percent drop-out rate as the young men learn more of what God is calling them to do, and as they face the sometimes hard-to-accept vows which they must take."Every guy is dferent," said Bobby. "To be honest, Im not  percent sure  percent is the rate of drop out Ive experienced over the past few years Ive been there. Theres only been two or three guys out of - whove left."Me, personally, my first year was probably my toughest year. It was a big adjustment from that freedom I had, and having gone from earning quite a healthy wage working at sea, then going to seminary in a foreign country ndash it was quite a challenge."There was a period where I did have to really, seriously, pray about it and think about what I was being called to do."I think everybody goes through it, and I think its a good thing that everybody goes through because ultimately thats what seminary is about.,params: .push"Seven years isnt a number plucked out of mid-air, its a period where youre doing a lot of study but youre also doing a lot of work to understand what it is youre being called to do, andits being called to priesthood because its not a light undertaking, its quite a serious undertaking ndash but a good one, and a positive one."And the problems facing Bobby and his fellow seminarians have only grown since the COVID- lockdown.He added: "From about six weeks ago being in Rome and studying in the university with my class of about  other guys, Im now sitting in a dining room in a Catholic church house in Galashiels studying on my own."So things have changed quite a bit. But study still continues, its not like theyve stopped. Theres been a couple of weeks, this week and last week, which would have been the Easter holidays anyway."Although we may be spread out, back to our home countries, were still persevering with study."And in June, Bobby hopes to sit his exams which will see him move into his seventh year at the Scots College. However, he intends to continue with a further year of study once his seven years are over to focus on his specialist course.Priest School will be broadcast on BBC Scotland on Sunday, April , at .pm and will later be available on BBC iPlayer.

title: borders-golf-club-asks-donations-ensure-survival
story: A BORDERS golf club fighting to survive the coronavirus pandemic has raised thousands of pounds in the coursersquos th anniversary year.Torwoodlee Golf Club, near Galashiels, has launched an online fundraising page in a bid to stay afloat.Club chairman Robin Brydon told the Borderthat generous donors gave a total of pound, within seven days.Mr Brydon said: ldquoItrsquos been amazing and wersquore all totally humbled by the donations so far.The JustGiving pagedescribes the parkland course as one of the ldquofinest in Scotland, but goes on to outline the challenges faced by the club, which closed last month.A statement reads: ldquoDue to the devastating COVID- pandemic crisis affecting us all, the club now faces an uncertain future and we therefore need as much money as possible to survive the pandemic and beyond.Speaking to this newspaper, Mr Brydon revealed that the original aim was to generate pound,, but a wave of donations has prompted the target to be raised to pound,.Mr Brydon said: ldquoFor people who are not going to the golf club at the moment and spending money on teas and coffees and entry fees and who are maybe financially better off as theyrsquore not spending money, wersquod be gratefulthey could donate a little bit every week to the club.Asked what the money will be spent on, Mr Brydon said: ldquoIt all goes into the pot and itrsquos just to ensure survival. Wersquove obviously got a lot of outgoings with machinery rentals and buggy rentals and bills to play.Clubhouse staff have been put on furlough, according to Mr Brydon, but a greenkeeper continues to maintain the course, established in .Mr Brydon said the club has around  members, but ex-members have also been keen to show their concern.ldquoWersquove seen donations from as far away as Australia, said Mr Brydon. ldquoWersquove also had money from Aberdeen and from former members in Chepstow.A third of the clubrsquos income has traditionally come from visitors, said Mr Brydon, who explained the coursersquos appeal.ldquoItrsquos a really lovely course ndash the views and the scenery and the layout. A lot of the visitors have been coming for  years, he said.Mr Brydon put the chances of survival at around  per cent, adding: ldquoEverybody has got to remain positive, but there are so many unknowns at the moment.Outlining how much the club means to him, he said: ldquoIrsquove been a member for  years, so itrsquos a huge part of my le and my familyrsquos le. Itrsquos a spectacular place to be ndash we all take it for granted.Peebles Golf Club is one of the other clubs running a similar fundraising drive.

title: tapestry-county-artist-mark-declaration-arbroath-goes-display
story: Mr Crummy, who designed the Scottish Diaspora and Battle of Prestonpans tapestries among others, first created the Arbroath Tapestry design two years ago.And after nearly , hours of needlework by teams in Angus, led by Arbroath-based Linda Walker, it has been framed in a stunning three  casing made from oak dating back  years which was taken from Robert the Brucersquos estate.The finished tapestry features in a documentary video released online to mark the anniversary on Monday, which features actor Brian Cox reciting part of the declaration and looks at its impact on Scotland.The documentary also features work by East Lothian artist Andrew Hillhouse, from Cockenzie, who passed away in .Celebrations which had been planned to mark the anniversary this week have been postponed until next year following the lockdown.However the documentary was released on time and showed the finished tapestry in its display case which will go on show at Arbroath AbbeyMr Crummy said he was delighted to be involved in the tapestry which is expected to go on display at Arbroath Abbey.He said: ldquoTo see how a small idea which was started by Linda Walker in Arbroath, has grown and made a huge impact already, even before it goes into the new visitors centre at Arbroath Abbey.ldquoIt has been a privilege, like all the tapestries to work with amazing stitchers. Without them their craft, creativity and generosity there would be no tapestry.The central  portrays Robert the Bruce and Abbot Bernard of Arbroath writing the Declaration while the two smaller  represent the role and influence of the Abbey within Arbroath.The left  features William I, founder of the Abbey, along with a fisherwoman to reflect the importance of local fishing industry.The right  represents the many trades which were involved in building and maintaining the Abbey and depicts two Scottish nobles setting sail to deliver the Declaration to Avignon.The Declaration of Arbroath was a letter sent from Scotlandrsquos nobles to Pope John in Avignon on April , .Widely acknowledged as one of Scotlandrsquos most important documents, the thanniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath has inspired Arbroath , a highly impressive six-month programme of special events.

title: thousands-meals-delivered-incredible-project
story: Fundamental Foods has launched a crowdfunding page to help it continue the work of its dedicated team who are running two pantries in Prestonpans and Tranent and making deliveries to people in Tranent, Elphinstone, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans.Lorna Bellany, from the project, which is run by Pennypit Community Development Trust, said they had delivered , meals last week with up to , expected to be delivered this week.And she revealed the desperate situations some people had been living in as they tried to self isolate or stay at home.She said: ldquoWersquove had some amazing feedback from people from all backgrounds: we even found out that an elderly couple had only eaten corn flakes for two weeks prior to our support and therersquos many iniduals that were skipping meals as they didnrsquot know how long theircupboard stockswould last.Fundamental Foods is estimating it is now making more than  deliveries every day, not including the meals.The pantries, which are run out of the Pennypit Centre, in Prestonpans, and St Martinrsquos RC Church Hall, Tranent, also provide people with food bags, recipe bags, and toiletries as well as hot meals and pre-cooked meals.They received donations from local restaurants and food outlets who closed following the lockdown however stocks are diminishing and restrictions on shopping have not helped.Lorna said: ldquoWe are currently using donated foods to give out that we get through Fareshare, from the local store surplus, community donations and we also got a lot of donations from restaurants and food outlets that were closed after government advice which was hugely helpful.ldquoOur food donations are really kind however with shop restrictions in place and stores not having a lot of surplus - our stocks are diminishingquickly.ldquoWe are working closely with thelocal community councils, housing associations, GPs, day centres and health visitors to gain more referrals and reach out to those in need.Ruth Davie, Pennypit Trust manager, who is overseeing the Tranent pantry operations at the moment, has issued an appeal for donations to help continue the work.Donations of food toiletries can be dropped off at both pantries between am and pm.To help fund the project go to www.crowdfunder fundamental-foods

title: countryside-plans-branded-over-development-east-lothian-council
story: Plans to build the new houses at the site, next to Longnewton Farm, near Gford, were put forward along with three new homes being created within the restored steading building.They were rejected by planning officers as against the councilrsquos countryside policy.And at a Local Review Body meeting of East Lothian Council, an appeal against that decision was also rejected.It was revealed the site had been given the go-ahead for  smaller homes to be built there in the past however, they were planned to be constructed within existing buildings.The new proposals would see a number of buildings on the site demolished.Agents for the application said they approached East Lothian Council in  with a pre-application enquiry but were told the councilrsquos countryside policy was against new builds unless they met strict exemptions, and were advised to consider converting the buildings on the land.However, they said no consideration appeared to have been given to the previous approval of  houses on the site.They warned there was a ldquovery real risk of losing attractive traditional agricultural buildings which are understood to date from the thcentury,further deterioration takes place due to a viable and marketable development solution not being found.However, at the review body, Councillor Lachlan Bruce said a balance had to be struck between the importance of saving historic buildings and protecting the countryside.He said: ldquoI think in this case the officer was right to say that the balance here is out of kilter.Mr Bruce added that the councilrsquos countryside policy was one of the most important they had, to protect rural parts of the county.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who chaired the review body, acknowledged that the local authority had supported developments across the county which had seen old steading buildings restored.He said: ldquoLooking at the site, the steading is in really bad condition and needs work done to it or it will be lost forever however, I think this project is an over-development of the site.The review body unanimously rejected the appeal.

title: walk-scott-foundation-makes-18-000-charity-donation
story: East Lothian Foodbank, Wee Red Upcycles and Home-Start East Lothian have joined together in a new project to help as many families as possible during the pandemic.The Walk With Scott Foundation board were discussing how they could support dferent areas of the county.They decided to directly support causes that would have the greatest impact across the whole of East Lothian and donated the money to the project.Colin McGinn, ward councillor and board member, said: ldquoThe foundation is very keen to help East Lothian families and we want to make sure we have a big impact on the county.ldquoWe are tapping into their experience, knowledge and network to make sure we have that impact.ldquoWe were deciding on what our next project would be but no one knew this would happen.ldquoTherersquos going to be an increased need for lots of services like the foodbank and Home Start so the damage is going to begreat the need for them is immediate.ldquoThis money will allow them to fund over their agreed level and to expand to [fulfil] the needs of workers worrying about funds.He added: ldquoWhen Scott [Glynn] started the charity he was very clear he wanted to help local groups, specically groups who have already started and had groundwork in place but needed an extra push over the line.ldquoWe know that Scott would be  per cent behind this.ldquoWe desperately hope that this need is not there in a few months and hope that this will make a dference.The money will help buy a number of items such as food, drink, activities for children and other essential items.The items will be sourced locally to help support local traders during the current crisis.The Walk With Scott Foundation was started by Scott Glynn seven years ago.He died on New Yearrsquos Day aged .

title: hundreds-meals-head-hardship
story: As well as providing food to children who would usually get free school meals, cooked meals are being delivered to other families in need.A number of items have been donated by local businesses and members of the community, with meals being cooked by volunteers in the Port Seton Centre.Bryan Hickman, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chair, said: ldquoWersquove been delivering over  things a day to the community ndash itrsquos been a big effort in every part. Volunteers are making hot food in the community centre, others are picking it up and some are delivering it. It is all being done safely.Food items have been donated by a number of local businesses, including Seton Sands Holiday Park, which gave several snack items as well as cereal, fruit and drinks.The Seaglass Inn also donated essentials, as did the local Co-op, including an extra supply of bread that had been delivered.The Port Seton gala committee, who announced last month that this yearrsquos event is postponed, also donated money that would have been spent on this yearrsquos event.The local community council, Parent Teacher Association and Chalmers Memorial Church also contributed.Bryan added: ldquoMost of those we have been delivering to have been nominated by other people.ldquoTherersquos about  or  families that receive free school meals in the area and around  OAPs, so itrsquos a lot of people.ldquoThose that we have delivered to so far have come across delighted.Donations are still welcome and will be ldquogratefully received, as will those willing to offer their services as a volunteer.A fundraising page has also been set up to help fund the effort anyone wanting to donate can do so at gofundme f yyervtcDaniel Baigrie, community development officer at Port Seton Centre, said: ldquoIn Port Seton, the local community council have been awarded funds from several local community groups to provide food for the elderly, those impacted by the crisis financially, and which is a leline to people in the community.ldquoThere have been a number of very generous food donations from local businesses.ldquoThe community council are also managing phone calls for practical support.ldquoPort Seton Centre management committee and East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities service are committed to working collaboratively with partner agencies to support our community in this unsettling time.ldquoIf you know someone who would benefit from support please contact us.

title: coronavirus-leaves-dunbar-woman-stranded-australia
story: Lucy Hall spent a year planning the trip of a letime, where she hoped to work with an animal charity.However, less than a month after arriving in Australia, the former Dunbar Grammar School pupil found herself without a job and unable to fly home due to the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoThings were going great! I managed to find a job within the first week of being here so I was off to a good start.ldquoI had found numerous charity events and environmental gatherings I wanted to take part in and have applied to volunteer in an animal welfare charity shop.ldquoI was really happy and content.ldquoThe coronavirus has had a massive effect on my time here.ldquoI am very lucky that I have a safe place to stay but I have lost my job due to it and so now have no way of earning money.ldquoLike the rest of the world, we are now progressing into lockdown here and everything is closing so I cannot partake in any of the things I had planned or go anywhere I had wanted to go.ldquoMuch like thousands of other travellers, my big plans have come to a complete halt and Irsquom doing the complete opposite of what I had imagined Irsquod be doing.Lucy, , who is living in Cha Heights, in the outer suburbs of Melbourne, started planning her trip to Australia a year ago.She has family in the country and planned to travel around Australia before deciding whether tohome to Scotland or to extend her visa.Lucy said: ldquoI have an uncle in Australia so Irsquove always liked the idea of coming to visit since I was young but my final decision on coming was made in April  this is when I purchased my visa!ldquoMy original plan was to travel around Australia and work while I also did some charity animal welfare-based volunteering.ldquoI raised some money before coming here to allow me to volunteer doing things such as beach clear ups, conservation work and volunteering at animal reserves.ldquoI was looking forward to meeting new people and potentially building a le out here.Now, without a job, she is unable to earn money or buy a plane ticket back to her home on Dunbarrsquos East Links Road.She stressed there were many people much worse off than herself and that she at least had family taking care of her.However, she was concerned about her family at home and how they were coping with the coronavirus.She said: ldquoMy plans are being put on hold for now whilst I figure out what my next steps are.ldquoMy main concerns are being sensible and staying safe whilst ensuring my family back home are coping as well.ldquoI had a flight booked to come back to Scotland last week but it unfortunately got cancelled due to airports closing their doors to non-nationals.ldquoI guess Australia has been impacted much like any other country at the moment.ldquoEverything is slowly shutting down, people are losing their jobs and there are more and more rules being put in place each day to minimise the risk. Itrsquos a very uncertain and frustrating time for travellers trying to get home.

title: parliamentarians-oppose-planned-mcdonalds-drive-thru
story: Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, and Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, both SNP, are backing objectors.Although the plan for the drive-thru ndash proposed for thetownrsquos Tesco store car park ndash is still under consideration by East Lothian Council, the go ahead has now been given for signage.This includes a . metre-high internally illuminated totem sign, displaying the McDonaldrsquos lsquoMrsquo and lsquoDrive Thrursquo logos digital menu boards lsquoPlay Landrsquo sign for a childrenrsquos play area McDonaldrsquos text roof signs lsquoGold Archrsquo symbols, and lsquocollectrsquo and lsquopayrsquo lettering signs.Mr Beattie said: ldquoThere have been a number of proposals locally which relate to fast food establishments opening in the constituency, with the planning proposal for a McDonaldrsquos in Musselburgh as one of the most recent.ldquoI firmly believe that there needs to be correlation between planning and healthy eating strategies and that proposals should be well thought out in line with the needs of the community. When making planning decisions like this we need to take the health of our constituents into consideration.He claimed: ldquoWith this proposal in particular we must also think about the impact this fast food restaurant would have on the health of students at Musselburgh Grammar School which is only a short distance from the proposed site.Mr Beattie added: ldquoIt is also necessary to recognise that the extra traffic is likely to worsen congestion in this area. This is likely to have a negative impact on the health of constituents through pollution, as well as presenting a strain on the road infrastructure.ldquoI received a large amount of correspondence from constituents who were concerned about the opening of a McDonaldrsquos in Musselburgh and I wrote to East Lothian Council to outline these concerns, as well as to outline my own thoughts. I have asked the council to carefully consider the comments from the community, as the opinions of the local residents are of the utmost importance. It is highly important that the council listen to what the community want as they are the ones who will be affected by this decision.Mr MacAskill added: ldquoIrsquom aware of the considerable concerns in the community.ldquoThis seem entirely inappropriate given existing traffic congestion, current fast food provision and the likelihood of increased litter.ldquoIt may be becoming the norm where for large retailers to use their car parks as additional earners with drive thru facilities but this would cost the community dear.Opponents have started a petition in protest at plans for a restaurant in the Tesco car park, highlighting a range of concerns such as increased traffic congestion, litter and air pollution.The online petition lsquoNo McDonaldrsquos in Musselburghrsquo, spearheaded by local environment group Love Musselburgh C.I.C, currently has more than , signatures.If approved, the drive-thru would be built at the northern end of the car park at Tesco, near to the supermarketrsquos petrol station.A McDonaldrsquos spokesperson previously said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application for a new restaurant in Musselburgh which,approved, will create at least  new jobs for people in the local community.ldquoWe are working closely with the local authority to ensure our proposals are acceptable and address any concerns raised during the consultation process.According to documents lodged with the application, there would be seating for  visitors ldquowithin a relaxed, modern environment.Outside there would be  car parking spaces, including two disabled spaces, as well as space for bicycles.A supporting statement from McDonaldrsquos added: ldquoAfter a review of their property portfolio, Tesco have found that some parts of the existing car parks were underused and surplus to their requirements. There is consequently an opportunity to introduce a complementary use that would support the overall retailand enhance the range of facilities available to customers.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe application is currently pending consideration and will be reported in due course once the planning authority has completed its assessment of the proposed development.The petition can be viewed at change.org p east-lothian-council-no-mcdonald-s-in-musselburgh

title: work-restore-east-beach-halted-coronavirus
story: A bid to bring sand back to the beach and protect the nearby Lamer Street got under way at the beginning of last month.However, that work has been put on hold due to the coronavirus pandemic.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council told the Courier: ldquoFollowing the advice from Scottish Government to shut down non-essential construction sites, East Lothian Council took the decision that the Dunbar East Beach construction site should be temporarily closed until further notice.ldquoThe contractor made safe the site before leaving on Tuesday, March .The beach was previously a magnet for tourists due to its golden sands but the disappearance of the sand due to coastal erosion meant a drop in the number of visitors.Sand started to naturallyto the beach, which had become increasingly rocky, last autumn.The council has been weighing up what to do to tackle the problem for a number of years.Permission was given earlier this year to see work carried out, with hopes it would be complete by the summer, which may no longer be the case.The first phase of works would have seen the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of the beach, with the existing groyne refurbished.Further work would have seen rock armour put in place at the toe of the seawall.Temporary Traffic Regulation Ordershad been put in place to allow the movement of large vehicles through the town centre to the beach.Consideration had also been given to importing sand but that was ruled out.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, is the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment.He had stressed there were no guarantees that the work wouldthe beach to its former glory as it was down to nature.But he added: ldquoThe people we have taken advice from are some of the top consultants in marine engineering in the country.

title: vet-column-take-lead-find-dogs
story: The sight of all those beautul dogs often encourages people to consider a dog for themselves. There are obviously many reasons why you may be thinking about acquiring a new dog.Our receptionist Lesley Baillie ndash who works in both Dunedin Vets branches in North Berwick and Prestonpans ndash recently had to bid farewell to her elderly dog Millie, her companion and friend for many years.Lesley was devastated but knew she needed a companion to fill the void. She began to consider which breed or type of dog would be best for her.The arrival of a new pet is a very exciting time, but careful consideration should be made regarding the type and breed of dog you choose.Many problems we encounter in the practice are a result of purchasing a pet not suited to lestyle and family environment.There are, however, many benefits of owning a pet. Companionship is the most obvious.Having a pet to talk to and interact with can take away many of the stresses of daily le.Taking a dog for a walk provides exercise and helps in creating a healthy lestyle. Having a pet is known to assist in the recovery from illness. In fact, PATdogs are encouraged in some hospital wards to help patients on the road to recovery.Dogs come in a huge iety of breeds, shapes and sizes, so choosing a dog to fit your lestyle can be extremely dficult. It is best to do lots of research before contemplating buying a dog.Many dogs have natural instincts such as herding and guarding, and these should be considered prior to choosing a dog.Also consider how the pup was raised. Were they house or kennel reared There are seven main classes of dogs, each with their own characteristics:l Toy dogs: as the name suggests, they are small dogs but are generally high maintenance and require a lot of grooming. They are, however, dogs and not toys or accessories. Examples: Bichon Frise and Chihuahua.l Utility breeds: there are a iety of breeds in this class but most tend to be courageous extroverts so need good control. Examples: bulldog and Dalmatian.l Terriers: they hunt by instinct and are brave and tough. They may be generally small but require lots of exercise and play. Examples: Border terrier and Airedale.l Hounds: these hunt and can be quite aloof they are quite independent and often like to be with one owner. Examples: bloodhound and basset hound.l Working dogs: as the name suggests, they have specic jobs. They are intelligent and may be quite large and guard dogs. Examples: St Bernard and Samoyed.l Pastoral dogs: these are bred to work with livestock and are very intelligent. They require mental and physical stimulation and tend to be tough and need a role. Examples: Border collie and Belgian shepherd dog.l Gundogs: they find and retrieve game. They have amenable temperaments and are active and affectionate. Examples: springer spaniel and retriever.We cannot, however, forget the crossbreed dogs, which are by far the most popular dogs around. Their nature will depend on their breeding and obviously they come in a huge range of sizes.Nowadays, there a large number of crossbreeds which are designated lsquodesigner breedsrsquo. Breeders will tell all the advantages of these lsquobreedsrsquo, but be aware not only are there advantages attributed to the parents, genetic traits from both breeds may also be present and in veterinary practice, we do see a disproportionately high number of problems with these dogs.There are many questions you should ask yourself before considering buying a dog.l Are there young children in the family  A utility dog, such as a miniature Schnauzer, or gundog e.g. Labrador may be breeds to consider.l Is everyone in the family out of the house during the day  Are you really able to look after a dog  An independent cat may be the best option.l Do you live in a flat  Consider a toy dog, e.g. Chihuahua.l Are you fit and able to go for long walks  Then the working or pastoral dogs should be considered e.g. Border collie or Doberman.l Do you have any fur allergies  Consider some the soft-coated dogs such as poodles.l Do you have a large garden  The terriers enjoy running around in enclosed spaces, e.g. Border or Patterdale terriers.Lesley considered very carefully what breed she should choose.She knew she wanted a fairly active dog who would enjoy long walks and travelling in her campervan with her.She also knew she did not want an overly large breed. She works part-time so wanted a breed which could be trusted to be left for short periods but was also friendly and enjoyed loving, human contact.After much deliberation, Lesley settled on a Tibetan terrier.These are a medium-sized breed originating in Tibet.Despite the name, they are not terriers but actually working dogs.They are therefore very loyal and affectionate but also energetic and sensitive.Tibetan terriers have a mid- coat which is very soft and hypoallergenic so excellent for anyone with animal hair allergies, but does require a good deal of grooming.After searching far and wide, Lesley found a breeder who had just had a litter of puppies.So, after a few weeks and a long journey, wee Hetty arrived home with Lesley.She really is a cutie and was so well behaved when Lesley brought her to the surgery.She is settling in well at home and hopefully she and Lesley will have many happy years and enjoyable adventures together.The rewards of owning a pet are immense.With careful consideration prior to purchasing a pet, you can have a cherished companion for many years to come.Caring for them can sometimes be a challenge but should give great pleasure to owner and pet alike.

title: couple-toast-diamond-wedding-anniversary
story: The message came as a very pleasant surprise for Lyn and Alan Vaughan, who are living in self-isolation on the townrsquos Williamstone Court.Lyn said that, unknown to her, her daughter Julie had made contact with the relevant officials.ldquoThe letter from Her Majesty was as a huge surprise when it arrived, said a delighted Lyn.It was also thanks to Julie ndash though inadvertently ndash that the couple were able to celebrate with  members of their family and friends at a pre-anniversary dinner in La Potiniere restaurant in Gullane a few days before the coronavirus lockdown was imposed.ldquoJulie was going on be on a ski holiday on the actual date of our anniversary, so we had a family lunch at La Potiniere, said Lyn.ldquoDue to the lockdown we canrsquot see them now, so it was very fortunate that we got together that day.On the evening of their anniversary, they joined the applause for the NHS in their road.Lyn, , and Alan, , were both born and brought up in Birmingham.The couple met at a ballroom dancing class and got married three years later on March , .The couple moved to Scotland in the s when Alan was working as a chartered surveyor on the St James Centre in Edinburgh.They moved to Gullane in  and lived there for  years before moving to North Berwick so they could be closer to the railway station as Alan had become partially sighted.As well as Julie and Andrew, the couple had another son Chris, who sadly died in  from a brain tumour. They have six grandchildren and one great grandson.So what has been the secret of a happy marriage over  years Lyn says: ldquoFamily, friends, a sense of humour, and shared priorities .Alan says: ldquoPatience, and do as your we tells you!ldquoWe feel very lucky to live in a beautul area and have good friends and neighbours and be part of such a caring community, said Lyn.

title: returning-haddstock-festival-delayed-coronavirus
story: Haddstock was due to feature more than  acts at venues throughout the town next month.However, Rebecca Dover, from the organising team, confirmed that the festival, which was due to take place on May , and dates around that day, was now being planned for September.She said: ldquoNHS predictions are that this will not be over by the end of May and we feel responsible for doing the right thing for our performers, facilitators and the community.The festival was launched in  and headlined by Aberfeldy, who previously supported REM at Loch Lomond.Two-thousand people packed Haddington, with a similar number visiting the town the following year.Organisers decided to have a yearrsquos break in  with a view to the festival ing in .Now, despite the issues surrounding coronavirus, the organisers have vowed to ensure Haddington is rocking later in the year.Rebecca, who lives in the town, said: ldquoOur plan is to move the entire festival, as programmed, to Saturday, September , and Sunday, September , so put it in your diaries.ldquoWe have had a very understanding response from our performers and facilitators regarding the postponement and we look forward to seeing everyone in September.The festival promised an expanded programme, featuring not just music.Family and cultural events, authors and storytelling were all part of the plans, as well as a project with schoolchildren joining together to sing a song in school the day before the festival, before everyone comes together on Haddingtonrsquos rugby pitch to perform together.Headlining the festival, at the rugby club, are Check Masses, DMS and Callum Easter.The headline performance will be ticketed, with the rest of the festival paid for through donations.

title: tims-tales-squirrel-effect
story: Here is a wee tale I told my kids when they asked why they couldnrsquot go to a play park:Once in a forest there was a squirrel enjoying a feast, eating the seeds from a pine cone.Suddenly the squirrel smelt burning. She looked up and saw smoke, then noticed all the animals running from a fire that had broken out amidst the heather.The squirrel rushed down the tree and also began to run.But she did not run out the forest like the other animals, instead she stopped at a river. She dipped her bushy tail into the water then ran back.She stood a safe distance from the flames and then shook her bushy tail, sprinkling the flames with droplets of water. The flames fizzed for a few moments, but it didnrsquot make any dference.So the squirrel ran back to the river and once again dipped her bushy tail into the water and ran back to the fire.Once again she stood a safe distance but shook her tail, and once again sprinkled the fire with small droplets of water. As before, the flames fizzed for a moment but it made no dference.Just then a hare ran by and saw what the squirrel was doing.ldquoYou foolish animal, said the hare, ldquoyou canrsquot put the fire out by yourself.The squirrel looked at the hare and nodded.ldquoI know she said, ldquobut the forest is my home so Irsquom doing what I can do.Then she asked the hare, ldquoWill you help me The hare thought for a moment. He didnrsquot live in the forest like the squirrel, but it was important for him as he would use the forest often to eat bark and twigs when there was no grass to eat.ldquoI wouldI could, said the hare, ldquobut the thing is I donrsquot have a bushy tail like you.ldquoHmm thatrsquos true said the squirrel, ldquobut you do have long ears. You could use them.The hare stroked his ears.ldquoSo I do he said, ldquovery well I will do what I can do.And so the squirrel and hare ran to the river.The squirrel dipped her bushy tail into the river, and the hare dipped his ears, collecting as much water as possible.They both ed to the fire, and stood a safe distance away. The squirrel shook her tail and the hare wiggled his ears.They sprayed the fire with droplets of water, and as before the flames fizzed for a moment, but it made very little dference.Just then a wild cat came by. She saw what the squirrel and hare were doing.ldquoYou foolish animals, said the wild cat, ldquoyou canrsquot put out the fire, just the two of you.The hare looked at the wild cat and nodded.ldquoWe know he said, ldquobut the forest is our home and feeds us, so we are doing what we can do.Then the squirrel looked at the wild cat and asked her, ldquoWill you help us The wild cat looked at the squirrel and the hare, and licked her lips.Normally they would be a good lunch option. But the wild cat lived in the forest too, and without it her habitat would be gone.ldquoI wouldI could, said the wild cat, ldquobut the thing is, I am afraid of water.ldquoHmm thatrsquos true said the hare, ldquobut we are also afraid of you, but we will be brave and work with you to save the forest.The wild cat thought for a moment. ldquoVery well I will be brave too she said, ldquoI will do what I can do.So the squirrel, the hare and the wild cat all ran to the river.The squirrel dipped her busy tail into the river, and the hare dipped his ears, while the wild cat took a deep breath and bravely jumped in and quickly out of the water soaking her coat.They ed to the fire, and all three stood a safe distance away. The squirrel shook her tail and the hare wiggled his ears and the wild cat shook her whole body.They sprayed the fire with droplets of water, and the flames fizzed for a moment, but it made little dference.Just then, a golden eagle was flying above and saw the squirrel, hare and wild cat.ldquoWell thatrsquos something Irsquove never seen before, said the golden eagle to herself, ldquoa squirrel, a hare and a wild cat working together. I have to find out whatrsquos going on.So the golden eagle flew down and watched what they were doing.ldquoYou foolish animals, said the golden eagle, ldquoyou canrsquot put out the fire, just the three of you.The wild cat looked at the golden eagle and nodded.ldquoWe know she said, ldquobut the forest is our home and feeds us, so we are doing what we can do.Then the squirrel looked at the golden eagle and asked him, ldquoWill you help us The eagle had wide wings, and although he lived in the forest he could easily fly away and find another forest.But this was his home too no other forest had the memories this one had.ldquoI would like to help, said the golden eagle, ldquobut the thing is I have no bushy tail, no long ears nor a coat of fur.ldquoHmm, thatrsquos true, said the wild cat, but you do have many feathers.The eagle thought for a moment.ldquoSo I do, he said, ldquovery well I will do what I can do.And so this time the squirrel, the hare and the wild cat ran to the river, while the golden eagle flew above.The squirrel dipped her bushy tail into the river, and the hare dipped his ears, while the wild cat took a deep breath and bravely jumped in and quickly out of the water soaking her coat.Then the golden eagle swooped down and collected water in his feathers.They ed to the fire, and all four stood a safe distance away.The squirrel shook her tail and the hare wiggled his ears and the wild cat shook her whole body, while the golden eagle ruffled his feathers above the flames.They all sprayed the fire with droplets of water at the same time, and the flames fizzed for a moment.This time it made a little dference.The other animals of the forest, who were running away from the fire, suddenly stopped and stared at the squirrel, at the hare, at the wild cat and at the golden eagle.ldquoYou foolish animals, they all said, ldquoyou canrsquot put out the fire, just the four of you.The golden eagle looked at the other animals and nodded.ldquoWe know, he said, ldquobut the forest is our home and feeds us and has our memories, so we are doing what we can do.Then the squirrel looked at all the other animals, and asked them, ldquoWill you help us The fox looked at the deer, the deer looked at the pine marten, the pine marten looked at the capercaillie, the capercaillie looked at the buzzard all the animals and birds of the forest looked at each other and had a think.The forest was important to them all in dferent ways.ldquoVery well, they all said ldquowe will do what we can do.And so they did. Each animal did what they could do, no matter how little.And when all the little was added up, it became a lot. And finally they put the fire out and saved their forest.

title: plans-lodged-replace-gullanes-mallard-hotel
story: The -bedroom Mallard Hotel in Gullane would be torn down and replaced by a new -bedroom version, under plans from Structured House Group.The new hotel would have a larger footprint on the site, off the villagersquos East Links Road, with a secondary access at the rear from Hamilton Crescent.Parking would also be created at the rear of the building.However, the villagersquos community council has aired concerns about the size of the proposed development and how it would impact upon roads in the village.According to the proposals, now being considered by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, the plans seek ldquoto enhance and support the existing character and nature of the site.A basement in the building would be used by staff, accessed from the East Links Road end of the site.On the ground floor, a reception area and bar would be created at the eastern side of the site, with a connecting corridor linking the building to nine bedrooms at the Hamilton Crescent section of the site and also providing access to the stairs linking the building to the first and second floors.Views out over the golf course would be on offer at a restaurant on the first floor, with a further  bedrooms at the rear.On the second floor, there would be six bedrooms on the eastern side of the building, with two facing out over the golf course, and a spa and staff room at the rear.Members of the public were given the chance to look at early plans for the hotel at the end of November last year.More than  people attended the public exhibition held in the hotel.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was among those at the presentation.He claimed at that time there were two major issues, which he anticipated would cause concern among neighbours and residents.He said: ldquoThere is a strong view amongst people in the immediate area of the development site that it is an overdevelopment in terms of the mass of the building.ldquoIt is too big for the site and visually, from the east as you approach Gullane over the golf course area, it will encroach into the townscape, which is part of the conservation area.ldquoIt is higher than the existing buildings.ldquoThe biggest worry reflected by immediate neighbours is that there will be traffic congestion in the immediate area because the parking will be inadequate for the development.ldquoThe representatives of the community council have met with a group of neighbours who are very concerned about it.Currently, the two-star Mallard Hotel hosts  en-suite bedrooms, an -seatsuite, -seat dining room and a -seat hotel bar. Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who was previously chairwoman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horseriding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel would remain open prior to any development.At the time of the public exhibition, she told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing, really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us, is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.

title: public-can-report-businesses-not-sticking-covid-19-guidelines
story: East Lothian Council says environmental health officers across Scotland now have new responsibilities to ensure appropriate public health measures are being followed during the Coronavirus pandemic.And it said any shops which could not comply with the social distancing measures required will be forced to shut down.The new Health ProtectionRegulations  have given additional control to councils and police to close premises.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environmental spokesperson for East Lothian Council, said enforcement remained a last resort for environmental health officers.And he urged people to report any business where guidelines are not being observed.He said: "East Lothian Council in all cases will seek to encourage businesses to comply with the measures through stressing the risks to the public and the NHS.ldquoFormal enforcement will always be the last resort where businesses fail to comply or where social distancing requirements are compromised, putting public health at risk. This approach mirrors Police Scotlandrsquos lsquoPolicing by Consentrsquo policy.ldquoWe are asking local residents thatthey have any concerns regarding social distancing measures either not in place or not being observed in shops to email ehts@eastlothian.gov.uk.ldquoThe Environmental Health and Trading Standards Team will then allocate an Officer according to the nature of the complaint.

title: gas-network-upgrade-hold-due-coronavirus
story: SGN told local MSP Colin Beattie that, following the latest Government advice to stay at home, it has had to make changes to its usual ways of working.The company is only continuing with safety-critical and emergency work.SGN stated: "We know that during the coronavirus outbreak, our communities will rely on us now more than ever to keep them safe and warm. The safety of our communities and our employees will remain our number one priority in the weeks and months ahead."It added: "We will continue to operate the   National Gas Emergency Service across the south of England and in Scotland during the coronavirus pandemic.
